body_html:
@vinhqdang pd.factorize return a tuple; the encoded values and the index/labels.

if you need to know what 1 means you just need to save your labels as @terrytangyuan suggested

y_train, label_index = pd.factorize(df_train['v3'])
# label_index[1] would return the original value encoded to 1

In your case it would:

label_index[0] == 10
label_index[1] == 5
label_index[2] == 20
label_index[3] == 50
body_text:
@vinhqdang pd.factorize return a tuple; the encoded values and the index/labels.
if you need to know what 1 means you just need to save your labels as @terrytangyuan suggested
y_train, label_index = pd.factorize(df_train['v3'])
# label_index[1] would return the original value encoded to 1
In your case it would:
label_index[0] == 10
label_index[1] == 5
label_index[2] == 20
label_index[3] == 50
body:
@vinhqdang `pd.factorize` return a tuple; the encoded values and the index/labels.

if you need to know what 1 means you just need to save your labels as @terrytangyuan suggested

``` python
y_train, label_index = pd.factorize(df_train['v3'])
# label_index[1] would return the original value encoded to 1
```

In your case it would:

```
label_index[0] == 10
label_index[1] == 5
label_index[2] == 20
label_index[3] == 50
```
